docs.abstract: David Sedaris ponders names for his new house, Karen Kingsbury reveals she has special help writing her novels and Stephanie Garber unveils her gorgeous Pinterest inspirations.
docs.snippet: David Sedaris ponders names for his new house, Karen Kingsbury reveals she has special help writing her novels and Stephanie Garber unveils her gorgeous Pinterest inspirations.
docs.lead_paragraph: “If you had your tonsils out, your cat would be happy to eat your tonsils, if you put them in her bowl.” That’s probably not exactly what you expect to hear from an author flogging his book — unless that author is David Sedaris, whose new essay collection, “Calypso,” enters the list at No. 1. Sedaris finds inspiration in daily life — wearing a Fitbit, picking up trash, visiting his North Carolina beach house, the Sea Section. (He recently bought the house next door to the Sea Section, telling Money magazine, “We’re going to either call it the Amniotic Shack or Canker Shores.”) “In a lot of the stories nothing huge happens,” Sedaris says. “I spent a week at the beach with my family, but it wasn’t like anybody got into a car accident or someone broke into the house and stole things. But it still felt like a story to me. You know, how life feels like a story.”

docs.abstract: Shot as a tribute to David Cronenberg, it makes its U.S. premiere at David Zwirner gallery tonight. An exclusive clip appears here.
docs.snippet: Shot as a tribute to David Cronenberg, it makes its U.S. premiere at David Zwirner gallery tonight. An exclusive clip appears here.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Canadian-born artist Marcel Dzama is known for his Dadaist multidisciplinary work — drawings, puppets, dioramas — and his collaborations on standout music videos. He was an art director on “The Suburbs,” the inventive Arcade Fire short film, and co-directed the spooky “No One Does It Like You” for Department of Eagles.

headline.main: Marcel Dzama, Kim Gordon and Tim Kingsbury of Arcade Fire on Their Offbeat Short Film

docs.snippet: “Like Dandelion Dust” revisits the pain of a tug of war over an adopted child.
docs.lead_paragraph: There’s no denying that the acting in “Like Dandelion Dust,” an adoption drama directed by Jon Gunn from a novel by Karen Kingsbury, is superb.

docs.abstract: Miss Katherine Duffield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus Duffield of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Laurence Kingsbury, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Kingsbury Jr. of Hamden, Conn. Both families have summer places in Sachem's Head, Conn.

docs.abstract: Rod Stewart, 67, and the former Kiss drummer Peter Criss, 66, join other grandfathers of rock on the list this week.
docs.snippet: Rod Stewart, 67, and the former Kiss drummer Peter Criss, 66, join other grandfathers of rock on the list this week.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEHIND THE GREASEPAINT: The grandfathers of rock continue their assault on the hardcover nonfiction list this week, as Neil Young and Pete Townshend are joined by the 67-year-old Rod Stewart (new at No. 4 with his autobiography, “Rod”) and the 66-year-old former Kiss drummer Peter Criss (new at No. 7 with his autobiography, “Makeup to Breakup”).

docs.abstract: In her best-selling essay collection, “The Last Black Unicorn,” the star of “Girls Trip” writes about growing up in South Central Los Angeles.
docs.snippet: In her best-selling essay collection, “The Last Black Unicorn,” the star of “Girls Trip” writes about growing up in South Central Los Angeles.
docs.lead_paragraph: MAKING IT: Tiffany Haddish may have been spurned by the Golden Globes, but the comedian and “Girls Trip” star is holding her own on the hardcover nonfiction list — her book of personal essays, “The Last Black Unicorn,” debuts at No. 15. The book is, no surprise, every bit as rowdy as the movie. Haddish grew up in foster care in South Central Los Angeles, and for a time had a job as an “energy producer” at bar mitzvahs, where she was paid to dance enthusiastically and encourage other guests to have a good time. (“I was basically the Flava Flav of bar mitzvahs.”) In one memorable chapter, she explains how that gig led to a sideline pimping out her male friends. “If you’re doing bar mitzvahs, you’re going to meet old Jewish ladies,” she writes. “They started telling me how lonely they were and saying things like, ‘My husband’s not satisfying me.’” When one woman showed Haddish her collection of romance novels — “She had one that was like a slave thing or whatever. It was a big, strapping black guy on the cover, holding this passed-out white woman” — Haddish was inspired. “I don’t know any slaves,” she told the woman, “but I could probably hook you up with somebody big and strong.” Word spread, and Haddish thrived until the men realized they could cut their own deals without her. That’s O.K. She’s found other ways to put her people skills to lucrative use. On the copyright page, her publishers suggest stores file the book under “Biography and autobiography / Rich and famous.”

headline.main: Tiffany Haddish on Bar Mitzvahs, Pimping and Other Rites of Passage
